abstract.p: Warner Brothers Records executive vice president Matt Pierson letter on Ben Ratliff's July 16 article scores Kenny G for lifting vocal track from Louis Armstrong master tape to change it into something else (S)

block.p: Using a Jimi Hendrix performance to sell Pop-Tarts, though distasteful and, to some, sacrilegious, doesn't alter Jimi's artistic presentation. The music hasn't changed. But to take a Louis Armstrong master tape, lift off the vocal track and present it in a different light than the artist intended is something else entirely. For Kenny G to do what he did to Louis Armstrong was a major abuse of his power, and was unforgivable.

But to take a Louis Armstrong master tape, lift off the vocal track and present it in a different light than the artist intended is something else entirely. For Kenny G to do what he did to Louis Armstrong was a major abuse of his power, and was unforgivable.

I actually heard Mr. Gorelick for the first time the same night Pat Metheny did. As a 20-year-old music student, I was shocked to hear so many out of time, out of tune and harmonically suspect pentatonic licks. Most of the crowd responded on a very base level, cheering him on. During Mr. Metheny's performance, the crowd sat enthralled, having been reached on a truly deep level. That evening was memorable for two reasons: Kenny G showed the potential commercial appeal of instrumental music, and Pat Metheny's performance was the first of more than 100 times I've seen him live. And five years ago, I was lucky enough to sign him to Warner Brothers Records.
The writer is an executive vice president of Warner Brothers Records.
